article_title: Burger King's Move Should Spare It Some Tax -- HEARD ON THE STREET
article_text:
While Burger King insists that relocating its corporate throne is not aimed at reducing its taxes, the deal may still help it do just that.

Responding to widespread speculation that the purchase of Tim Hortons represents a tax inversion—a deal pursued primarily to avoid U.S. taxes—Burger King points out that its effective tax rate last year was 27.5%. That is in line with the Canadian chain's effective tax rate of 26.8% for calendar...

twitter.description: Buying Tim Hortons in Canada is seen by many as a straightforward tax inversion. Even if it isn't, there could still be less-obvious tax benefits for Burger King.
twitter.title: Burger King's Move Should Spare It Some Tax

image.alt: Burger King's move should spare it some tax.
